div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents per week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.p:
Runaway from the Medical College. June 23d a bright Mulatto Boy named Frank He is about 12 years of age, stoops slightly, and walks awkwardly.--When last heard from he was on the Central Railroad track, saying that he was going to Tennessee.
All persons are hereby warned against harboring him. The usual reward will be paid for his delivery to A. E. Peticolas.
Richmond Va. June 24 1861 je 25--ts

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay the above reward for the apprehension of Jesse, who left my farm, in Chesterfields, about three weeks since.
He is of rather low stature, though stout, light, ginger, bread color, and about 27 years of age. His acquaintance about Richmond is extensive, and I think he is lurking about there, as he has been seen at Howard's Grove, cooking for the soldiers.
je 25--6t* H Carrington Watking.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, on the 29th day of May, a Negro man named John Oakry; has a wife at Robert P. Warring's, in Essex county, Va. John is of light, ginger-bread color, 5 feet 2 or 3 inches high.
I will give $20 reward, and pay all necessary expenses for him, to be delivered to me in Richmond, or in Tate's jail.
je 22--6t* James Robinson.

committed to the jail of this county, on the 24th day of April, as a runaway, a Negro calling himself Dave Wheelee, who says he is free and from Lunenburg county.
Said Negro is 5 feet 4 ½ inches high; about 55 years old; a dark brown color and complains of his right knee being stiff.
He will be dealt with according to law.
Brown & Tyree, Jailers.

je 12--2w* Chesterfield county.
Va.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p: --Runaway from the farm of Mr. James Lyons, on the 22d of day May, a negro man, named William Foster, He is a mulatto, and has a bushy head, about 5 feet 10 inches high, of down look when spoken to. The above reward will be paid for the apprehension of said fellow, if delivered either to Mr. James Lyons or Dr. Eo. B. Lyne in Richmond.
ja 17--tf Thos. L. Lyne.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway, a Negro Man named Horace, about 35 years of age, of light brown color, weighs 180 pounds, and walks very slovenly; had on light grey coarse woolen clothes.
He is the property of Dr. Tiffin, of Mar. and.--Address Pulliam & Co., or

je 12--20t* W Crawford.
Richmond. Va.

div3.head: The circulation of the Dispatch.
div3.p:
Such is the wonderful amount of the circulation of the Dispatch. that it is utterly impossible for us to supply it to our city readers as early in the morning as heretofore.
This has occasioned numerous complaints, and we very much regret our inability to obviate the difficulties out of which they have grown.

Some of our regular subscribers are under the impression that they are neglected to accommodate the transient demand.
They are mistaken in this.
There is no arrangement in the office intended to give any such preference over them.
On the contrary, all of the regulations in the department which governs the distribution of the paper are intended for their advantage over all, after the malls are sent off.

If we can accomplish our plans, we shall, in two or three months, have the power to meet the large demand upon as promptly and satisfactorily.
If human energy can achieve this, it shall be done.
In the meantime we ask the indulgence of our friends.

div3.head: Notice to our subscribers.
div3.p:
Subscribers to the Dispatch will observe the Cross Mark on their papers when their subscriptions are about to expire.
Those who wish to renew will forward the amount, or the papers will be stopped at the close of the term for which they have paid.

div3.head: Send us the News.
div3.p:
Our friends at the various camps and places of rendezvous and elsewhere, will confer a favor by sending to us any interesting intelligence, at the earliest practicable moment, for publication.
We desire to keep our readers informed in regard to everything that transpires, and will pay an adequate compensation for important news.

div3.head: Prussian officers.
div3.p:
We know not whether it is true that the King of Prussia has given two years leave of absence to sixty officers of the Prussian Army for the purpose of offering their services to the United States.
If so, it is an unfriendly act, and presents a marked contrast to the strictly neutral position taken by Greet Britain, which not only prohibits officers in her service from joining either side in this country, but forbids all her subjects, whether in military or civil life, from taking up arms in the American contest.
We are not surprised; however, that a despetic military power like Prussia should sympathize with a military despotism like that which Lincoln is endeavoring to establish in America, and it may be that the system of white slavery, which, under the name of free labor, is endeavoring to force African slavery from every portion of this continent where Europeans can be substituted, has something to do with the course of the Prussian Government, as it unquestionably has with the compact and enthusiastic support given by Germans in all the free States to the present war. Whatever the motive, we have no apprehensions of these military adventurers — these Dugald Dalgetty's--whom Lincoln is importing from Europe to lead his Hessians against the Southern States.
Prussia ought to know by her own history the power of a patriotic people to defend their own firesides against the greatest odds, and if she does not know it, her deputies will learn a lesson which she may be called upon to imitate, perhaps with indifferent success, before many years.
She has an eagle eye on her own continent that looks upon her with no peculiar love, and the day may come when the boundaries of France must be rectified.
Louis Napoleon, who has already humbled Russia and brought Austria to her marrow-bones, has a small account yet to settle with another Kingdom of Germany.
He bides his own time; but the time, though long deferred, always comes at last.

div3.head: Noble-Hearted ladies.
div3.p:
--One of the agents on the Weldon and Wilmington Railroad informs us, that when a military train arrives from the South at Whitaker's Station, the ladies residing on the farms within a circuit of several miles flock to the station, bringing with them an abundance of food for the hungry soldiers, which they serve out with a liberal hand.
This welcome provender generally consists of fresh butter and milk, cooked chickens, hams, bread, brandied peaches, preserves, and in fact, every luxury of the farm.
The soldiers depart with a stomach and haversack full of good things, while the ministering angels wave their handkerchiefs, kiss their hands and bid them God speed.

div3.head: Episcopal action.
div3.p: --The Diocesan Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of South Carolina, last week passed unanimously a preamble and resolutions approving the secession of the Southern Church, which the people of the North have forced upon us.

div3.head: The position of Kentucky.
div3.p:
--Notwithstanding the large Union majorities obtained in the recent Congressional elections in Kentucky, it seems to be believed that the State will only await the action of the coming extra session of Congress before determining her final course.
A correspondent of the Philadelphia North American says:

q.p:
Should that Congress sustain the action of the Government in its war measures, and refuse to adopt such means as may appear acceptable and honorable to bring about a peaceful settlement of pending difficulties.
then will the fate of Kentucky be cast with that of the South.
In furtherance of this, Mr. Crittenden's first act will be the offer of his previously rejected compromise, accompanied by a speech, which will leave no doubt of the determination of his State should the olive branch be again rejected.

div3.head: Dull Times in New York
div3.p: --The following is an extract of a letter from New York city:

q.p:
The fashionable hotels continue to suffer severely from the pressure of the times.
The suspension of Southern travel, of course, is almost total, in consequence of the war, and as that sort of patronage was always the most profitable, the lack of it now is severely felt.
The few arrivals daily recorded hail principally from the New England and Western States, but even these are like angels' visits--"few and far between."

The newspapers, too, continue to suffer from the state of the times.
The Courier and Enquirer, on the 1st of July, it is said, will be merged into the World.
The Journal of Commerce, like the Courier, a mercantile organ, has also been compelled to curtail its dimensions, owing to a lack of advertisements.

div3.head: A supposed privateer.
div3.p:
--Capt. Curtis, of the ship Windsor Forrest arrived at New York on Sunday from Liverpool, reports June 13, when S. E. from Carryafort Reef, fell in with a schooner of about 140 or 150 tons, who followed in his wake the greater part of two days, when, she being unable to come up with him, and several other vessels having hove in sight, she handled her wind and stood in for the Bahamas.
From appearances, he thinks she might have been a privateer, as she had more than the usual number of men on deck and a look out man at each mast-head.

div3.head: Smoothing
div3.p:
--We learn from the Fredericksburg Herald that a difficulty occurred at a parade at Aquia, Stafford county, in Capt. James Waller's company, on Saturday last, between Lewis Knight and another member whom Knight threatened to shoot.
A friend named Ennis remonstrated with Knight, and whilst approaching him the third time, Knight raised his gun and killed Ennis.
Knight fled, but was arrested and is now in jail.
The Union House at Niagara Falls was burned on the 22d inst.
Charles W. May, a Lieutenant in the Navy, from Maryland, has resigned.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
camp life at Forktown — the remains of Maj. Winthrop, &c.
div3.p:
I verily believe that routine life in camp is almost as hard as fighting.
Nobody was ever known to like the drill, especially when it is inflicted upon your unawakened senses, which have barely enabled you to recognize your own name at roil call.
Nor does the drill enliven you more under the blaze of the noonday sun, seeing that it involves a trial of speed between yourself and restive artillery horses.
But for the glorious privilege of grumbling, which is inalienable, with a sprinkling of what "our army" did terribly in Flanders, I don't know how we should get along.
We bathe at certain times — being denied the right of blistering our backs by a midday "wash," as in the glorious time of yore, in the August vacation, we did. We drill and swelter, and swelter and drill.
We scramble for your paper when the boat comes, devour the good things which kind friends and relatives send us with an avidity which should melt the heart of a commissary, eat oysters imprudently, and angle vainly for fish which bite not, neither do they nibble.

We are under a fighting commander here, and I must say that we are frequently afforded opportunities to indulge in that sort of thing.
Expeditions towards the enemy are frequent and fatiguing.
The only incident with which I can leaven this lump of generalities, occurred in one of these recently.
A Major Winthrop, you will recollect, was killed an Bethel.
A day or so ago, whilst we were in that neighborhood, a flag of truce came in with a request for the body.
Several of our company were detailed for the disagreeable duty of disinterring and escorting it to the outpost.
We were met there by an officer in the U. S. Artillery, with two or three men, one of them a New York Zouave and a brother of the deceased.
During the transfer of the remains to the coffin, which had been brought, our boys conversed a good deal with the Zouave and the other men. The Zouave was communicative — that is, he communicated a good many falsehoods; at the same time he tried to pump the boys, but without success, I think.
He said significantly, that he meant to go back to New York alive, and that he would like to see anybody get him away if he ever got there.
The blockading steamer left us a few days ago, and several pungees availed them selves of the opportunity to slip in, and doubtless will turn an honest penny in the way of freights on York River.

Four deserters from Old Point, who had found their way to Matthew's county, were brought here yesterday, and I learn that a Yankee prisoner was brought in to-day.
We have enough men here to cope with any quantity of the enemy.
Nobody is frightened, and nobody cares how soon the enemy comes.--There are, of course, many disagreeable and hitches inseparable from camp life; but if the cause is worth anything, it behooves us to bear them patriotically; and we do. A retrospect will comfort use and nerve us to far greater trials.
The sufferings of a Valley Forge, and the countless marches over weary miles by our forefathers, show what a people seeking to vindicate their rights can bear.
Civilization renders a return of these almost impossible; but in contemplating those trials, our's sink to an insignificance which amounts to the ridiculous, and in this light only have I touched upon them.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Affairs in East Tennessee and Southwestern Virginia.
div3.p:
The Union party of East Tennessee is being rapidly merged into the ranks of the "Southern Right" majority of the State.
But for the doings of Yankee Maynard, Trigg, Baxter.
Nelson, and other leaders, the transition would be more rapid.
"Toady" Johnson has gone North, via Cumberland Gap and Louisville, Ky., at both of which last-named points he is reported to have made speeches.
In a speech at Tazewell, Claiborne county, Tenn., he stated "that if his Union friends would but stand firm, in six weeks men and means and guns would be supplied them" by the route through which the vile scoundrel and Tory has been allowed to escape.
"Forewarned, forearmed." Let Gov. Harris see to it that no Lincoln mercenary be allowed to pase into Tennessee by Cumberland Gap.
Let every wagon and box of merchandize be ripped up and searched to the bottom.

A volunteer in a German company, from Mobile, Ala, (Corporal Block, I believe,) was severely wounded by a shot from the pistol of one of his company; the ball took effect in the leg, entering midway between the knee and ankle near the shin-bone, passing out behind, through the calf, inflicting a severe flesh wound.
The Corporal is doing well at the house of a gentleman of Bristol, where he is well cared for. He will be about in a few days; the bone was not fractured as I am told.

We had quiet an-exciting time here Saturday, a company of Texas volunteers got in pursuit of a Union lawyer from an adjoining ville in Tennessee, the frightened "Knight of the green bag" took refuge first in the parlor of Mr. A., thence he was taken to the "cockloft" of his (Mr. A.'s) counting-house, after that he found more safe quarters in the livery stable of a friend, and lastly, a la Lincoln, he left (although it was very hot, thermometer, at 90, at sunset,) wrapped in an old overcoat turned many sides out and drawn well up around the ears, entering the Tennessee train by the rear entrance, without a ticket; when asked if he had a ticket he answered no, damn the ticket!
" Alae, poor Joe!" all this for voting the "Union ticket, and setting in the Tory Greenville Convention."

The harvest is now ripe, and such an one we have rarely seen in any county.
Wheat is excellent, grass better, potatoes and corn fine, oats a little injured for want of rain in the past few days.

Washington county has five new companies in camp and two being organized; our county will soon be represented by 13 companies in the field, and plenty more left behind for at least five more good companies.
Gov. Floyd's Brigade is fast filling up; 18 companies are now at or near Wytheville, enrolling for his line of operations.

A Natchez cavalry company of 80 picked men, with their fine horses and outfit, passed here on yesterday, bound for the seat of war. You must see this company of gentlemen to appreciate them.
A better equipped and more gentlemanly company will be hard to find.
They travel at their own expense, as we learn.

Col. Moore, we understand, will have command of the regiment now forming in this brigade.
"Somebody hurt" again.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
military spirit in Albemarle.
div3.p: As communications are constantly appearing in your valuable paper in relation to the military matters in different sections of our beloved old Commonwealth, I deem it due to the gallant people of Albemarle to let her sister counties know what she has done for the purpose of driving from her soil Lincoln's miserable horde of Northern hirelings.

In the first place, Albemarle has appropriated $50,000 towards arming and equipping her volunteers.
In addition to this, a large private subscription has been raised, to be expended in providing for the families of the volunteers.

Albemarle has already sent eleven companies to the war, to wit: Capt. Duke's, Capt. Mailory's, Capt. Davis, Capt. Taylor's, Capt. Peyton's, Capt. Crank's, Capt. Timberlake's, Capt. Winn's, Capt. Ray's, and one company from Scottsville and one from Howardsville, the names of whose Captains are not remembered.

In addition to this, Capt. Hill, of Scottsville, has just organized another company in that gallant town, and Capt. Robert Coles, son of Ex-Governor Coles, of Philadelphia, has organized still another on the South side of the county.

I should have mentioned sooner that Capt. Peyton Coles, also of the South-Side, has raised, mainly at his own expense, a fine Cavalry company.
These three, added to the eleven already in the service, make fourteen in all, with the almost certain prospect of the organization at an early day of an Artillery company in this place, and at least one or more of Infantry.
So that we may safely estimate that in 10 days from this time our county will have some fifteen or 16 companies in the field.
This, I think, will do tolerably well for glorious old Albemarle.
Let her sister counties follow her noble example.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Abundant harvest in North Carolina.
div3.p:
We are at this time in the midst of wheat harvest, and a more productive crop was never garnered in this section.
You can say to the invaders that as soon as we are done with the wheat harvest, we intend coming over to reap the Yankees from the soil of Virginia; and we are just the boys that can mow them down.
It is nonsense to talk of starving us out. We have any amount of breadstuffs and meats and fish.
Mr. Wm. Glovert, of Elizabeth city, caught at one hasl 600,000 herrings.

There are no want of soldiers to defend our homes and firesides.
This county, though small, (giving only 600 votes,) has now in camp 300 men, ready and anxious to march to the aid of Virginia.
A company of Connaught Rangers has been organized in New Orleans for the war.

div3.head:
[communicated]
the crop Lean.
div3.p:
There is a very general misconception abroad, even among the press — those who ought to know better, and whose means of information leave them no excuse for such ignorance — with reference to the plan adopted by Congress, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to accept subscriptions for the defence of the Confederacy in the shape of raw productions.
It has been supposed by some that the cotton and other produce thus pledged to the Government, was to be controlled and sold by the latter, which would thus interfere with individual enterprise and the great commission business of the country, and divert itself from the legitimate purposes for which the Government was established.--It has been supposed by others that the Government desired to control the cotton crop, that it might, by withholding it from market, dictate our recognition by European Powers.
A reference to the act of Congress itself will show that that body never contemplated nor authorized the Government to be "launched into the business of a huge commission house," nor to control the sale of the produce subscribed in any way, shape or form.
The act reads as follows:

q.p:
"The Secretary of the Treasury may, with the assent of the President, issue $50,000,000, in bonds payable at the expiration of twenty years from their date, and bearing a rate of interest 'not exceeding eight per cent, per annum,' until they become payable, the said interest to be paid semi annually.
The said bonds, after public advertisement in three newspapers within the Confederate States for six weeks, to be sold for specie, military stores, or for the proceeds of sales of row produce or manufactured articles, to be paid for in the form of specie, or with foreign bills of exchange, in such manner and under such regulations as may be proscribed by the Secretary of the Treasury, with the assent of the President."

div3.p: It will be seen from the terms of the law, that the bonds are to be exchanged for specie, military stores, or for the proceeds of the sales of row produce or manufactured articles, to be paid in the form of specie or foreign bills of exchange; that the Government does not hold the produce subscribed, nor concern itself with its sale, further than holding a lien upon it for its proceeds; that the subscribers merely pledge the proceeds of so much of their crops, in their own hands or those of their factors, the same stipulated to be disposed of by a certain day agreed upon.
The subscription lists read as follows:

q.p: "We, the subscribers, agree to 'contribute to the defence of the' Confederate States, the portion of our crops set down to our respective names; the same to be placed in war choose or in our factors' hands, and sold on or before the first day of — next; and the net proceeds of sale we direct to be paid over to the Treasurer of the Confederate States, for bonds for same amount, bearing 8 per cent interest."

div3.p:
There can be nothing more simple and clear than such a transaction, and we are surprised that there should be such a misapprehension regarding the modus operandt by which, while the Government is to be supported on the faith of the growing crops, it is to confine itself to the legitimate and simple business of exchanging its bonds for specie and military stores.
We repeat it is a mere pledging of the proceeds of the crops.
Thus lightening the burden to the people, and yet enabling the Government to carry on its military operations, on the faith of productions not yet gathered, but pledged for its use when gathered.

As to the plan of appealing directly to the people for money to carry on the Government, that is the very mode which has been adopted and is now in operation.
We know not indeed what amount has been subscribed in the State of Virginia, but we do know that in the Cotton States a very large sum has been subscribed by the masses of the people towards the Confederate Loan, in amounts of $50 and upwards, and the door is still standing open.

In all our Southern cities and towns, the Commissioners appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury to receive subscriptions lost no time in giving the people an opportunity to invest small sums in these bonds, and it was eagerly availed of. The Richmond Commissioners have, we understand, made no report of the amount subscribed here, and we doubt if sufficient publicity has been given to the fact of their readiness to receive contributions from the class of citizens to whom we refer.

The plan now in operation of receiving subscriptions of raw produce was considered and discussed at great length, and in all points of view, by a body of intellectual men, composed of a Stephens, a Toombs, a Cobb a Hill, and a Rhett, as well as many other brilliant and judicious and practical minds and we may be very sure that the right thing was done, at the right time, and in the right manner. A. B.

div3.head: A Scrap of history.
div3.p:
--The language as well as the spirit of the North, in the present war, seems to be borrowed from that of the British invaders during the war of independence.--Lord Cornwallis issued, in 1780, in regard to the State of South Carolina, which was then assumed to be a British "province," as it is now deemed to be a province of Lincoln's empire, the following order.
It sounds like an editorial in some New York paper in 1861, and in the very vein of the champion of Northern supremacy:

q.p:
"I have given orders that all the inhabitants of this province, who have subscribed and taken part in this revolt, should be punished with the greatest rigor; and also those who will not turn out, that they may be imprisoned, and their whole property taken from them and destroyed.
I have also ordered that compensation should be made out of their estates to the persons who have been injured and oppressed by them.
I have ordered, in the most positive manner, that every militia man who has borne arms with us and afterwards joined the enemy, shall be hanged.
I desire you will take the most rigorous measures to punish the rebels in the district which you command."

div3.p: This letter fell into the hands of Washington, and was made, with the similar orders issued by Lord Rawdon, the topic of indignant remonstrance with Sir Henry Clinton, their superior officer, to whom some modifying letters were written by these officers, to mitigate the enormity of their acts.

They would need no mitigation in order to make them conform to the bloody minded counsels of the Lincoln press of this day.--On the contrary, the tone and almost the very words are renewed every day through their columns.

It is another part of history that, in little more than a year after this letter was written, Cornwallis himself was a prisoner to these same "rebels," and as a retribution which his fallen pride deserved, his sword was surrendered to the very General who had been forced to capitulate at Charleston.

We are reenacting history.
What has been, will be.--New Orleans Picayune.

div3.head: Production of hay.
div3.p: --We are gratified to observe that the agriculturists of the South are bestowing attention upon the culture of hay. The Columbia South Carolinian, of the 22d inst., remarks:

q.p:
The season for saving hay and fodder will this year be industriously turned to account, and these are articles particularly needful.
Yesterday we saw several wagon loads of bales of hay from Charlotte and Greensboro', N. C., which seem equal to any from the North.
We trust our supply will in the future be from our own rich meadows of our own mountains and upper country.
Buncombe produces as fine hay as the North River, and we lack only cheap transportation to be as fully supplied as we have been from Yankee land.
Last spring, while on a boat on the Alabama River, the captain mentioned that over ten thousand bales of Yankee hay was carried from Mobile to Montgomery; and our towns — and we are ashamed to say our country residences — have been supplied heretofore by Northern hay.--But this is now past; we hope, forever.
Our people have the record before them of Northern hatred and efforts to continue their oppressive taxes on Southern industry, and they have the facts forcibly impressed upon them that we can support ourselves.
We only want energy and industry in the right direction to free us from the bondage we have so long allowed to shackle us.

div3.head: From the Dominican Republic.
div3.p:
--Letters just received from Port-an-Prince, state that Gen. Santana, who has assumed the title of Captain-General, caused the parties who had been arrested at Moca to be tried by court-martial.
Five were condemned to death and were shot, and forty to hard labor for life.--No Spanish officer or soldier was a member of the court-martial, nor did the Spanish troops take any part in the execution of the sentence.

An arrival at New York brings later advices from St. Domingo. Five important towns in the interior of Dominica have been fortified.
The Dominicans were assisted by the Haytians, and intend to resist the Spanish progress.

It was reported that the inhabitants of a village has been massacred by the Spanish troops, because they refused to swear allegiance to Spain; and also, that the Spanish troops were defeated in a small engagement.
A planter in Ribb county, Ga., has reclined $112 per acre from the sale of cats at 75 cents per hundred pounds.

div3.head: Movements of the Confederate Army
div3.p:
--Serious Destruction of Railroad Property--The Southern army under General Johnston, lately occupying Harper's Ferry, is reported as being posted, 20,000 strong, in the vicinity of Martinsburg and Winchester.
Martinsburg itself has been occupied for several days past by Brigadier General Jackson, with a force of about five thousand men, a goodly proportion of whom are cavalry.
On Friday and Saturday last a general destruction of the locomotives and cars belonging to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad at and near Martinsburg, was made.

Our reports state that over forty locomotives, of the largest and best description, with several old and less important ones, were almost entirely demolished, by heavy fires of wood and coal being built under them.
Some three hundred cars in all, including several passenger cars, and about one hundred wooded box and platform cars, (which might have been adapted for the carriage of troops,) were burned up completely, while the round iron coal cars — some two hundred in number — were emptied of their contents, and a portion of them run down the neighboring embankments, or into the bed of the streams whose bridges were previously destroyed.

Our informants state that the immediate reason of this wholesale destrustion was a hand-bill, (since discovered to be a forgery, having been entirely without their authority or knowledge, yet purporting to be issued by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, and said to have been posted at Harper's Ferry and other places in Virginia,) to the effect that the company wanted two thousand men at once, at two dollars a day, in order to restore the bridges and put the road in order for the use of the Federal Government.
This movement is believed to have been a ruse by interests hostile to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to deceive the Southern authorities, so as to lead to the destruction of its property.

General Johnston, Commander-in-Chief, believing that such a repair and use would seriously operate against his cause, is said to have given the order to General Jackson for this additional damage to the road, thus putting it on the ground of a military necessity.--There are many rumors in circulation with regard to this affair, but we believe the foregoing to be its true phase.
Our information satisfies us that it is the intention of the Southern authorities to spare no effort to prevent the road from being worked for the use of the Government in any part of the State where they can maintain sufficient force to defeat it. It is stated that the passage of the Potomac river by General Cadwallarer and his command, subsequently followed by his retreat across the same, were among the causes which induced this action by the Confederate army.
It is further stated that the vacillation of the movements of the Federal forces for so long a period after the evacuation of Harper's Ferry by the Confederates, led to their return to its vicinity, and also to the re-occupation of Martinsburg.--Baltimore Sun, 25th.

div3.head: A Curb for DiarrhŒA.
div3.p: --Numerous requests having been made to republish the recipe for diarrhŒa and cholera symptoms, which we gave in our paper some weeks ago, and which was used by the troops during the Mexican war with great success, we give it below, with a very important correction of an error made in the first formula, as to the size of the dose to be given:

Mix all together.
Dose — a teaspoonful in a little water, or a half teaspoonful, repeated in an hour afterwards, in a tablespoonful of brandy.
This preparation will check diarrhŒa in ten minutes, and abate other premonitory symptoms of cholera immediately.
In cases of cholera it has been used with great success, to restore reaction, by outward application.--Phila. Inquirer.

div3.head: A gun fired by the enemy's shot.
div3.p: --Capt. Casper W. Hunt, of the Walker (Tennessee) Legion, present at the attacks on the batteries at Aquia Creek, a few weeks ago, narrates the following as one of the hundred hair-breadth escapes of the Confederate forces on that occasion: "One man was lying sick in a house near battery No. 1 when the firing commenced; he seized his musket and ran out of doors with it in his hand; at that moment a shell exploded over his head, and a fragment of the shell striking the hammer of his gun, fired it off, not injuring him in the least."--Fred Herald.

div3.head: Suspected.
div3.p:
--A Parts correspondent writes: "An aged Commodore of the United States and a Naval Captain have just arrived here from Washington, on their way to China, to take the China fleet out of the hands of a Commodore whose fidelity to the Stars and Stripes is suspected, and bring it home.
The mission is a secret one, but by the time this notice returns to Europe it can do no harm, as the officers go by the English overland mall route, and will soon be out of the way of of telegraph."

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 147, page 2.

div3.p: Our Norfolk and Portsmouth correspondents should bear in mind the fact that their letters lose all value unless mailed so that we can get them on the night of the day on which they are written.

A lady from Texas who came with the Volunteers of that State to nurse them, it is said, is exposed to much hardship at Camp Jackson, since she has no tent to protect her from the weather, and is following up the noble object of her journey with many other discomforts.
Her case deserves attention, if it be properly represented.

div3.head: Muzzling the press.
div3.p:
The Northern journals entertain their readers with periodical essays upon the peculiar characteristics of free speech and a free press which distinguish American civilization, and are sorely exercised over the restriction imposed upon the press of France.
We venture to say that a more complete despotism was never exerted over the minds, tongues and pens of men than has prevailed from the beginning of this war in most of the Northern cities.--Some men have been shot down in the streets for expressing opinions in favor of Secession.
If a Northern man ventures to say, as thousands of them, Fillmore among the number, said, before the war, "If I were a Southerner, as I am a Northerner, I would never be ruled over by a sectional despotism," it is denounced as high treason.
How long will it be before a people who are thus intimidated from giving utterance to their thoughts, will cease to think at all, and become the ready slaves of any aspiring military genius who may seek to grasp a crown?

What wonderful progress must liberty and the right of free discussion have made in that section which is eternally boasting of progress and freedom, when, even as long ago as the American Revolution, Chatham, standing in the midst of a British Parliament, could, without molestation, aver the same principle for which, at this day, a Northern citizen must be branded with treason.
He could exclaim, in the midst of a war, not as unjust and abominable as that which the North is now waging against the South, "If I were an American, as I am an Englishman, so long as a hostile foot trod upon the shores of my country, I would never lay down my arms — never, never, never." If the subject of a monarchy could utter with impunity such sentiments, what are we to think of the Republicanism which denounces the same freedom of speech as high treason, and holds the terrors of brute violence over every citizen who dares to exercise it?

div3.head: Patriotism of the ladies.
div3.p:
We are in the beginning of the war, which may be long; but however short, it is one which cannot end without considerable bloodshed.
There will, therefore, be a good deal of suffering among the wounded and the sick, and it may be greatly alleviated by the kind and gentle ministrations of the ladies, who know so well how to promote their comfort and soothe their sufferings.
Mrs. Judge Hopkins, of Alabama, has presented a noble example for the emulation of her countrywomen.
She, is untiring in her zeal, and has just visited Manassas to organize, if possible, a hospital, properly attended by nurses.
We trust that our own daughters of Virginia, near whose homes the battles must be fought, will combine to institute efficient and practical measures for the benefit of our gallant volunteers.

We are informed that a society is just organized in King William, of which Mrs. E. H. Tebbs is President and Mrs. B. J. Lewis, Vice President.
They will make clothing and render any assistance in their power to the soldiers.
A Burke is Secretary of the Society — his address, "Acquinton, King William county." Such societies may do a great deal of good.
They should endeavor to organize an active and efficient system in the State, at least in the vicinity of the seats of war, as far as possible to supply the wants and relieve the sufferings of the volunteer.

div3.head: Tennessee.
div3.p:
A citizen of Polk county, Tennessee, communicates, through the columns of the Dispatch, some interesting neighborhood news to the volunteers from that county, selecting this medium because the officials of the Lincoln Post Office (not yet abated as a nuisance in the county) send all letters addressed to the soldiers of the Confederate army to the dead-letter office, at Washington.
It is quite refreshing to read so unsophisticated a relation of home news in the columns of a newspaper.
But what an admirable example we have in the simple statement of the letter: "The young ladies of our county, many of them, have been working in the corn and wheat fields, and say, 'as long as they (the volunteers) stay to fight, we will make them something to eat!' Wheat noble women they are!
Can they ever be other than the wives and the mothers of freemen?
No — never!

div3.head: The Thirteenth of June.
div3.p:
A patriotic and intelligent correspondent calls attention to the remarkable fact that the day recently set apart for fasting, humiliation and prayer, was the natal day of Gen. Scott, he having been born on the 13th June, 1785. He asks if it was so ordered by design that the national observances alluded to should take place on that day, or was it accidental?
It was entirely accidental, and therefore what he terms "Providential." In that case, he suggests that it is "ominous for Gen. Scott and his party." The fact, if he has been reminded of it, no doubt, startled the commander of Lincoln's myrmidons, and caused the pay for which he has sold his mother Virginia, to burn his hands, as did the thirty pieces those of Judas Iscariot.

div3.head: Fulten street prayer Meetings.
div3.p:
A friend of ours has, on several occasions, expressed much solicitude to know what has become of the "Fulton Street Prayer Meetings" which were so famous during the depression of business in New York a few years ago. We were unable to give him any information.
New York must always have a hobby of some kind — dramatic, religious or political — at present it is martial — but is never constant long.
The "Fulton Street Prayer Meeting," whatever may have become of it, does not seem to have produced much of the peaceable fruits of righteousness.

div3.head: Medicine, contraband.
div3.p:
We believe that never till the present highly humane and civilized war have medicines been made contraband.
Yet even before the open rupture, Northern apothecaries refused to sell quinine and other articles in their trade, and since the war, none whatever are permitted to cross the border.
The inhumanity which thus makes war upon the sick and afflicted, is, we believe, unparalleled in the history of civilized nations.
There is, however, this consolation, that medicines in general kill more than they cure.

div3.head: Reports of British and American trade.
div3.p: A compaction of lats annual reports of British and American trade, shows some curious facts in regard to what Americans and Englishmen eat and drink, and otherwise consume.

In regard to coffee, the United States consumed nearly five times as much as Great Britain, whilst the consumption of tea, on the other hand, was nearly seventy-four millions of pounds in Great Britain to not more than twenty-nine millions here.
The annual consumption of sugar in Great Britain was 847,693,400 lbs.; here, 437,029,020 lbs, of foreign sugar, twenty-four and a half millions of molasses — a good deal of it made into rum — and three hundred pounds of cane and maple sugar, made in this country.
Of cocoa, the annual consumption of Great Britain, more than three million pounds; here, not quite one million.
The British annual consumption of wine is 6,697,146 gallons, and of brandy, though the English duty is very high on brandy, gin, &c., 1,108,115 gallons; rum, three and a half millions of gallons; gin, 26,238.
Although the old United States duties were also high on brandy, the consumption was as great as in Great Britain.
Of imported "spirits, from grain and other materials," including cordials, our thirsty population imbibed 2,769,383 gallons, and, in addition to this, disposed of any number of barrels, hogsheads and pipes of "Old Bourbon,""Young Bourbon,""Apple Jack,""Stone Fence,""Rot Gut,""Medford Rum" and "Blue Ruin," all made in the model Republic, and by the "most intelligent and virtuous people on the face of the earth." So much enterprise has been shown in this admirable branch of American manufactures that, over and above our own immense consumption, we have exported as much in one year as 5,024,735 gallons.
The Sons of the Pilgrims achieved a spiritual conquest even over the Disciples of the Koran, the faithful in Egypt being enticed by Brother Jonathan to forget the teachings of Mahomet to the extent of 8,500 gallons of New England rum; Turkey in Asia, 330,120 gallons, and Turkey in Europe, fifteen hundred thousand gallons. If the present war does not interfere with the progress of American civilization, we may expect New England will convert the Turks entirely from the errors of Mahomet within the next twenty-five years. Nor has that exemplary section withheld its benignant influences from the benighted sons of Africa, but has beneficently distilled 900,000 gallons of the Puritan's delight into her thirsty throat.

In regard to tobacco, there pass through her Majesty's Custom-Houses annually fifteen millions of pounds of stemmed tobacco, and more than nineteen millions unstemmed.
The United States imported from Havana nearly three hundred millions of cigars; from other foreign countries nearly ten tons of snuff, and six millions pounds foreign tobacco in other shapes.
After exporting in the leaf and manufactured nearly thirty millions dollars worth of tobacco, more than fifty million pounds must have been retained for domestic use.

Great Britain, with an area of not quite 120,000 square miles, enriches her lands with 353,541 tons of guano.
This is more than double the quantity employed by the United States, with an area of nearly three million square miles.
The largest customers of England were India, which, exclusive of Ceylon and Singapore, buy the annual amount £16,782,515; 2d.
The old United States £14,013,083; 3d.
Australia £10,464,198.
The greatest purchasers from the old United States were--1st. Great Britain, (exclusive of colonies,) about £168,105,848, (mostly Southern productions;) 2d.
France, £32,741,917; 3d.
Cuba, £14,433,191.

Whether the world can long stand the interruption of such a trade, remains to be seen.
It must be a good deal more than a paper blockade that is going to keep England and France out of Southern ports.

div3.head: The question of a King.
div3.p:
The Northern press, in giving themselves so much concern about the alleged willingness of South Carolina to live under a King, are in blissful unconsciousness that they are themselves at this moment the subjects of a despot compared with whom George the Third was one of the mildest of monarchs.
An Executive who tramples the Constitution of his country under foot and usurps all power, is none the less a despot because he retains the name of President.
If South Carolina were to prefer a monarchy, it would probably be a constitutional monarchy, which would at all events be an improvement upon the unlimited monarchy of King Mob and his Lieutenant Lincoln, by whom the whole North is now ruled with a rod of iron.

It requires no prophet to predict that the North is already ripe for a King, and that to that complexion they must come at last.
The ductility with which they yield to the extraordinary usurpations of Lincoln, their disregard of all law, the perfect recklessness with which in disregarding the constitutional rights of others, they set a fatal precedent for the future sacrifice of their own, demonstrate that they are not capable of self-government and not fit for freedom.
If the South ever becomes monarchical, it will be some centuries after the North has set the example.
The crowded population of the Northern States, and their heterogeneous character, will render necessary, for the protection of all the great interests of society, a strong Government, upheld by a considerable standing army.
Therefore, we commend them, instead of speculating upon the alleged proclivities of South Carolina for monarchy, to be looking out for some competent person to succeed the present usurper, and as a faithful type of the dominant party of those States, we would recommend them to crown Greeley, of the Tribune, who has proved himself the master of their editors and statesmen, under the name, style and title of Horace the First.

div3.head: Maryland and Missouri.
div3.p:
We are satisfied that the invaders at Washington will have their hands full to accomplish the subjugation of these two States--The injuries and oppressions they have visited upon their people are keeping alive volcanic fires of vengeance, which only need a suitable opportunity to break forth into irresistible fury.
Heaven speed the glorious hour of retribution!

div3.head: Bath Alum Springs.
div3.p:
--A correspondent writes in highly commendatory terms of these Springs as a place of safe resort at the present time.
"Our people," says the letter, "are loyal and zealous in the great cause of the South, as shown by their votes and their eagerness to volunteer"

div3.head: Election in Fauquier.
div3.p:
--An election was held in Fauquier county on the 19th inst., to fill the vacancy in the Convention occasioned by the death of Capt. John Q. Marr.
The candidates were Ex-Gov. Wm. Smith and James V. Brooke.
The latter was elected by a majority of 92.

div3.head: Promotions.
div3.p: --Colonels Wm. J. Hardes and Bankhood Magruder have been appointed Brigadier Generals in the Confederate Army.

div3.head: The Buner fight.
div3.p: --The Baltimore Exchange, of the 24th instant, says:

q.p: As up to the present there have been no correct official refuse of the killed or wounded at the late of the are anxiously awaiting the report of General

div3.head: A publishing House.
div3.p:
In reply to correspondent who makes inquiries touching a publishing house for the South, we can say that the principal book sellers of this place have all done something of book publishing in a limited way. We do not, however, know of any strictly publishing house at this time.
The want will no doubt soon be supplied, and after the war we shall be publishing better books than the North have heretofore given us, in a style certainly as good as theirs.
Our correspondent could no doubt have his Southern school book printed by some one of the book houses of this city if they approve it.

div3.head:
[Communicated.]
to the Second company Polk county Tennessee Volunteers:
div3.p: Numerous are the letters which have been written by your friends at this place since your departure, and many kind ones have we received from you; but, sad to say on yesterday morning we received the painful intelligence that as yet you had heard nothing from us. The fact has caused a considerable degree of excitement among our citizens, and upon inquiry it is found that all letters directed to volunteers now in the Confederate States are sent to the dead letter office, and knowing this fact, I avail myself of this opportunity of addressing you through the columns of the Daily Dispatch, hoping that it may perchance fall into your hands.
As far as I know, no sickness exists in any of your families, but, on the contrary, good health prevails among all.

Wheat is all harvested, and such a yield we have not had for years.
The corn crop looks very good, although we have had a little drought.

The election came off on the 8th, and as you may have heard, the State went for separation by about 55,000.
Your own beloved little county of Polk went for separation 738, no separation 317.
The 2d District voted 157 for separation, and 23 against it.

The Brownlow party met at Greenville last week, got up a row, kicked W. M. Biggs, and some others that were not sufficiently ultra, out, and drew up a set of resolutions to be presented to the Legislature, now in session, desiring to withdraw from the State, and establish a separate State.
Some of them are beginning to talk very large about what they are going to do, and Andy Johnson, knowing that he dare not show his face in Virginia, sloped around through Kentucky, and is now in Washington city, making preparations, as he said, to send 10,000 troops into East Tennessee, to protect their mammoth (?) Government among the mountains.
But woe to them if they commence it, as there are 40,000 volunteers yet in the State, and they will eat the B. R.'s of East Tennessee without greasing.
Your families have all been well provided for by the County Court.

Messrs. Hancock, Reid, Runnion, and others, are making up another company, and have already gotten some 40 names.
They talk of going just so soon as wheat is threshed.

I think we will get you the required number of men you desire pretty soon.
Send me directions of how they shall manage to get to you.
The young ladies of our county, many of them, have been working out in the corn and wheat fields, and say "as long as they (the volunteers) stay to fight, we will make them something to eat."

We understand that you sent back a box of carpet-bags, boots, likenesses, &c. They have never been received or heard tell of. William McKamy started to you last week, but has not been heard from, and his folks are getting uneasy about him.
Hoping that these few lines may reach you, I remain yours in bonds of true friendship,

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Exposure of Federal falsehoods.
div3.p:
Is it a part of a Northern man's being to cheat and to lie, or is it the result of circumstances over which he has no control?
I have been induced to propound to you and your intelligent readers this question, from reading in the Dispatch, of the 24th, a paragraph taken from an Alexandria paper relating to Col. Early's Regiment, in which I have the honor of being a member.
The paragraph to which I allude, reads as follows:

q.p:
"A force of eight hundred men are in the neighborhood of Occoquan.
They refused to let any of the wood boats of Occoquan or Neabsco, come up with the wood or barrels, in consequence of which, as it is all the dependence the poor people have in that neighborhood, great suffering is experienced.
Hugh Hammond, a very worthy citizen of Prince William, a Union man, was taken prisoner and very rudely handled."

Now, this is the most notorious falsehood which has yet come to my notice, as I shall show.
On the 15th of the present month, our Regiment, the under the command of Lieut. Col. Hairstone received orders to march to Occoquan; we arrived there on the evening of the same day, and early on the morning of the 16th we were ordered to march back to our encampment, which was about thirteen miles distant from the village.
So you see that we only remained in the village twelve hours.--This fact is sufficient to show upon what a frail foundation a Northern man is capable of manufacturing a stupendous lie. When the Regiment arrived at Occoquan, a party of six of our men (of which the writer of this was one) walked down to the river, and observed several vessels riding at anchor.
About half a mile from the town we unloosed a small skiff from its fastenings, and in this we went to the nearest vessel, for the purpose of bathing.
This boat, together with all the rest, was loaded with wood; and when we mounted upon the deck we found that there was not a man upon her but ourselves.
As soon as we had finished bathing we quietly returned to the camp.
Our party had not a single weapon upon their persons at this time.
This gave rise to the paragraph in the Alexandria paper.

I will now offer to old Abe a mathematical proposition, and earnestly entreat him at his earliest convenience to furnish me with its solution, which of course he can do very readily, being a good mathematician; for not long since he very wisely said that, "mathematically it was necessary to subdue the South before he could collect the revenue in the seceded States." If I have not quoted him exactly, I humbly ask his forgiveness.
But if unfortunately for the human race, the august President of the United States is so absorbed in contemplating horrors which he and his party have entailed upon the country; if that brilliant mind once so strong and powerful is now shaken from its balance, or impaired in power by visions of Southern bayonets; if, in fine, his mathematical talent has now, in his time of need, forsaken him, he will confer a lasting favor upon the writer especially, by soliciting the aid and services of the world renowned and awe inspiring "Fuss and Feathers." The proposition — if six unarmed men can blockade a port and capture a whole fleet, and reduce to the point of starvation the entire population of a once thriving village in 12 hours, what can one or two hundred thousand patriots, defending their rights and liberties, armed to the teeth and defended by Heaven, accomplish in 12 yea rs, if up to that period the war shall last?

It is true that we took a prisoner at Occoquan.
He was a suspicious character, but for want of evidence against him he was released.
He was not maltreated.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
the Prisoners captured near Yorktown.
div3.p: In a late issue of your paper I notice a communication over the signature of "Musketeer," about which I desire to say a word.

After speaking of the detachment that was sent out by Col. Hill from Bethel Church the Saturday before the battle of the 10th June, under the command of Lieut. Col. Lee, he says "Col. Lee's command took one prisoner, and this was the first capture made in the skirmishes preliminary to and provocative of the battle of Bethel Church." In the first place the detachment that left camp under Col. Lee being composed of a part of Company "F" and one howitzer of the Richmond battalion, did not capture a prisoner at all.--The fellow was run down and taken by a party of mounted men under the command of a gentleman of the name of Phillips, who joined Col. Lee's detachment somewhere on the road.
I do not doubt that "Musketeer's" friends would have killed and taken a goodly number of Yankees; but the truth is, they did not get within three quarters of a mile of them, and therefore the infantry who did not fire a shot cannot claim the Yankee as their prize or even that of the Regiment.
In the second place, I have Col. Hill's word for it, that the skirmish of the same day, much nearer Hampton, in which the advance guard of Major Lane's detachment, under command of Lieut. Gregory, killed and wounded some fifteen or twenty of the enemy and took one prisoner, was the true cause of the attack and consequent discomfiture of the enemy on Monday, the 10th of June.

The Colonel told the officers of our company the evening after the battle of Bethel, that we alone were responsible for that day's work, and that he had learned from the Rev. Mr. Adams, a Baptist clergy man of Hampton, that he saw two carts and a buggy loaded with the killed and wounded, Saturday evening after the skirmish, going into Hampton.

We claim, in accordance with these facts, that the detachment under command of Major Lane, consisting of the whole of Company "E," 1st Regiment North Carolina Volunteers, and a howitzer under Lieut. John. M. West,"--by-the-way, as clever as follow as ever fired a gun — by their dash almost into the enemy's stronghold, provoked the battle at Bethel Church, and that the first prisoner captured by the Regiment was the one taken by their advance

div3.head:
From camp Shenandoah.
[Special Correspondence of the Dispatch.
div3.p:
We are now encamped in the woods about four miles from Winchester, Va., awaiting orders.
We have returned this far from Romney.
The location is cool, pleasant and agreeable, and just far enough from the town to keep the soldiers orderly.
I have no especial news to report.
Our camp consists of three regiments, viz: Tenth Virginia, Col. Gibbons; Thirteenth Virginia, Col. Hill, and Third Tennessee, Col. Vaughan, making a total of near 3,000 men. All three of them are fine regiments, and made up of good men, who are "game" throughout.
Colonel Hill, late of the U. S. Army, is commandant at this post.
The men are all well and in good spirits, and seem to enjoy soldier's life exceedingly, and make no complaint, except they want a little "fire-water," which they cannot get, as none is allowed to be brought to the camp.

Great numbers of ladies come out from the surrounding towns to see the camp and soldiers, daily.
There are numbers of fine country residences surrounding camp, the proprietors of which do all they can for the comfort of the soldiers.
I enjoyed, with some others, the hospitality of Col. Robert.
Glass a day or two since, in the way of a fine dinner.
Long life to the Colonel.
He is every inch the gentleman.

The crops in this section look particularly well.
The wheat looks especially fine.
No danger our army will starve, as the crops are the finest I ever saw. No news of importance.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
how a Connecticut Captain was taken — the Hunters of Kentucky, &c.
div3.p:
I must lay before your readers the history of the capture of Capt. Kellogg, of the Second Connecticut Regiment, by two gallant young Kentuckians, members of a company of six who are here from Kentucky, acting in the capacity of independent scouts "It seems that this party were near Falls Church, where they had been concealed for two days and nights, waiting for an opportunity to seize a squad of pickets posted on Flint Hill, about three hundred yards from the encampment of the enemy.
Two of them, leaving the remainder of their company some distance off among the pines, started out to reconnoitre, when suddenly they fell in upon Captain Kellogg, in the yard of a widow lady by the name of Scott, who lives within the lines of the enemy, and about 200 or 300 yards from their encampment.
The Captain had with him three valiant comrades, who, upon seeing their leader surrender, fled precipitately to camp.
Twenty-five pickets, stationed but a few rods further up the hill, witnessed the seizure of Kellogg and the flight of his companions, and they, too, believing that "discretion was the better part of valor," and in their imagination converting every bush into an armed man, made the best of their way back to their camp, congratulating themselves doubtless on their fortunate escape.
Now, we can see of what "stuff they're made"--nearly thirty men, armed and equipped, routed by two Kentucky boys.
The names of these two Kentuckians are, Mr. Shanks and Mr. Crow, who, as we are informed by them, reside in Lincoln county, Kentucky, and who but a week or two since brought over a company of Kentuckians to join the Confederate Army; but which company unfortunately wanted a few men to complete a regularly organized corps, and consequently were disbanded.
The company, I understand, was conducted hither at the individual expense of the two gentlemen named, they being the officers in command.
The deed mentioned in the foregoing deserves the commendation of all lovers of heroism.
It was a heroic act, and speaks volumes in favor of Kentucky chivalry and daring.
I am assured by Messrs. Crow and Shanks, that Kentucky will certainly unite herself with the South at no distant day; that she is with us now at heart, and thousands of her sons, who have been rendered heart-sick at the temporizing of their State, are ready to come forth to battle when ever patriotism and the necessity of the South shall demand their services.
You needn't be surprised if you hear ere long of "somebody being hurt."

div3.head:
[Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch]
the brush at Edwards' Ferry — the enemy frightened off with Stove-pipes.
div3.p: With your permission, I wish to correct a statement of the brush at Edwards' Ferry, in your edition of the 21st inst., copied from the Baltimore Sun, but which originated in the Washington Star.

The real state of the case was this: Upon bearing that the enemy had advanced as far as Edwards' Ferry, on the Maryland side of the river, Col. Hunter, stationed at Leesburg, 4 miles distant, ordered one company of Infantry thither, to take their position on the Virginia side, to act as a guard and to harass the enemy as much as possible in case of an attempt to cross.
In fact, I cannot say with certainty that there was a whole company sent, at any rate not more at that time.--So that there was no regiment visible, and consequently no intention to march upon Washington.
Their fire was directed to an officer and several citizens, I think, who were crossing Goose Creek, which runs into the Potomac at this point, neither of whom was struck, nor was any one of the company there.
So no officer was killed, and certainly not "six men, or, as some suppose, more."

The day before this some of our men at the ferry proposed to their Captain that they should put up an extensive fortification.
Consent was given, and for the purpose they used several barrels of cement which had been left on the shore of the river.
These were rolled up to an elevated point directly opposite the Lincolnites, who watched the progress of the would-be fortification with seemingly great interest.
After putting all they could get into their proper place, they went into the ferry house and took two pieces of old stove-pipe, and carrying them to the breast work, placed them in such a position as to be easily seen by the enemy on the opposite bank, and who no sooner saw the ends of the pipe protruding from the fortification than off they put at "a double quick" up the branch.
The ruse had the desired effect, showing that they could be easily scared, and was laughable in the extreme.
So they did run.

I write this to place our troops in their right position, as they intend to show that they cannot be driven back in regiments so easily as the Star would make one believe, in close quarters, much less with the Potomac river between them and the enemy.
But what cause can hope to succeed, when it requires such false statements to bolster it up in the eyes of its friends?
Nothing can be gained by falsehood, but it is to be hoped that something may be by

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
military matters in the Valley.
div3.p:
Our boys are gone.
The Allen Infantry, a gallant, soldier-looking company, left Thursday morning for Winchester, in fine spirits, ready and anxious to meet the foe. Previously to their leaving, religious exercises, consisting of an address and prayer, were conducted by the Rev. A. R. Rude.
Every member of the company was also furnished with a copy of the New Testament.

The evening of that day saw the 116th Regiment Virginia Militia quartered in Mount Jackson.
Quite a number of the men were armed with their heavy rifles, used at shooting matches.
As an evidence of the loyalty to the South and the determination of the people of the valley to battle for their rights, we would mention, that although this regiment is mainly composed of farmers, but few of whom own slaves, yet they cheerfully left their homes, the grass and the grain being nearly ready for the mower and the reaper, and obeyed the call to march, which came to them Wednesday, so readily, that in a few hours the whole regiment was en route.
As soon as the harvest is over, almost any number of men can be had from the Valley counties.
The militia wants, however, two things badly: officers and drilling.
They possess all the qualities for making excellent soldiers, but they stand greatly in need of drill masters.
Would it not be a good plan to distribute such throughout the Valley?

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
military spirit in North Carolina.
div3.p:
Thursday, 7 o'clock A. M., we forwarded per steamer Cotton Plant, via Newburn, our third instalment of soldiers, the "Jeff. Davis Rifles," Capt. J. R. Carmer, 80 men, for the war. No finer body of soldiers have gone forth in our country's service from any quarter.
Each counts himself a man, and all will vie in manly acts when dangers are to be encountered.
This, with two companies previous, have been fully equipped, (except arms,) and sent forward within eight weeks by the ladies of Washington, and a fourth company, under Capt. Tom Marsh, from the lower part of the county, will leave this week.
With Capt. Swindell's "Confederate Guards," which were from another part of the county, and left some three weeks past, we have five companies in the field--four in the Old Dominion and one on our seacoast.
This will do pretty well for Beaufort county.
But when Abraham gets his 500,000, we will send as many more, if not sooner.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
what Albemarle has done.
div3.p:
Old Albemarle has covered herself all over with glory by what she has done in the noble cause in which we are embarked.
She has only some thenty-three hundred voters, and has organized seventeen companies, ten or twelve of which are now in active service, and the others will be off in the course of a week.
If the militia were called out, there would not be haft enough men left in the county to take care of the crops.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
more about the fight at Carler's Creek.
div3.p:
Having returned from viewing the demolition caused by Lincoln's fiendish cut-throats.
I will proceed to give you a brief description: On Monday evening, the 25th inst., the Federal steamer Star came in the Rappahannock river, and went up about ten miles from its mouth, and then turned and came down to Pope castle, a fam lying eastward of Carter's Creek, in Lancaster county, Va., belonging to Mr. James Gresham.
She then sent off a large barge and two smaller boats.
The barge came as near the shore as she could get, and then the fiends got out of the barge into the smaller boats and landed.
In a short time after they had landed, Capt. Hathaway came down with his company and fired on the barge, which was lying some distance to the right of the small boat that had landed.
The barge had a cannon mounted on her bow, and a large number of armed men in her. When Capt. H's men fired on the barge, Lincoln's heroes, that had landed, were so badly frightened that they retreated in every direction.
Some took to the boat and others ran into the river.
The presumption is that some of them were drowned.
All the white Jeff. Davis's men incessantly showered bullets upon Old Abe's weasels.

The steamer commenced firing about 4 o'clock P. M., and continued until 6 o'clock. She fired sixty rounds, seventeen balls passing through Mr. G.'s dwelling-house.
His house is entirely demolished.
It is standing, but is completely useless; every room is shattered.
Mr. Gresham's wife and mother were in the house during the bombardment.
The mother, who has been bedridden for some time, was lying in her bed, when a cannon ball passed through her room, struck the head of the bedstead, and passed on between the sacking and mattress, and raised her up off of her bed without any injury.
She was then moved to another room, which was attached to the rear of the larger portion of the house, and in a few moments a bombshell passed through the apartment and exploded, striking the chair which she was sitting in, without doing her the least harm.
God will protect the righteous; He has been upon the side of truth, and will ever be.

One boat and a number of arms, consisting of pistols, muskets, rifles and sabres, was taken by our men. The loss upon the enemy's side is presumed to be eight or ten.
Our loss, mirabile est cavare, not a single man hurt.--The weasels killed one frog and a mouse.
What a victory!
What a triumph!
Our men fought like heroes, and clearly demonstrated that there still remains in the bosom of the Southern people the same high toned and patriotic principles that animated their ancestors in 1776.
The Lancasterians have shown to Lincoln's devils that they intend to die freemen rather than live slaves.
All honor and success to them.
That was the most atrocious and diabolical attack ever made.
It shows that they have blacker souls and more fiendish designs than ever was revealed by the annals of civilized war. Our banner may be stained by the blood of its defenders — it may be trampled upon by the unhallowed feet of Northern fiends, but it will rise unsullied and float triumphantly, redeemed by Southern sons, whose arms are nerved by a virtuous indignation, and whose hearts pulsate with a resolve to conquer or to die. We would give all the victory to God, and all the praise to His great name.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
doings in Eastern Tennessee.
div3.p:
The loyal citizens of this part of Tennessee are beginning to properly estimate the dangers which threaten them.
Although they live in the mountains, far away from the present scenes of the conflict, yet they are beginning to see that they, too, are likely soon to be involved in trouble.
The traitors of this section are busily at work to inaugurate a reign of terror among their own people, for the purpose of aiding Lincoln in his unholy crusade against Southern rights and Southern institutions.
Union companies are already being raised, with the avowed purpose of resisting the authorities of the State, and in some counties loyal citizens are apprehensive of danger to their persons and property from the ignorant, unemployed followers of Lincoln.
I have not yet seen a copy of the resolutions passed by the Greenville Union (traitor) Convention, but I understand they are full of treason and rebellion.
Judging the action of the Convention by the characters of some of its members, one could not be surprised at anything they would do. A few men of talent and blasted political aspirations moulded the pliant material around them according to their own pleasure, and made whiskey and ignorance vote just as their majesties chose they should.
The consequences are, treason and rebellion are loudly talked of in East Tennessee, and the strong arm of the military will soon be required to put it down, unless the hope of aid from Lincoln, through Johnson, becomes lost, and they see their cause is desperate, supported only by such a rabble as they can gather.

Two companies belonging to the second East Tennessee Regiment, got off the cars at this place yesterday, their destination being Cumberland Gap. Two Cavalry companies are going there by other routes, and perhaps the balance of the regiment will be sent there in a short time.
As the route would be through a sparsely inhabited Union country, it would be an easy matter to send a large force from Ohio, through Kentucky, to that point, and besides, that is the only way that arms can be sent here to Union men; consequently, the precautionary step of sending troops there is a good one.
I hope soon to hear of brilliant Southern victories on Virginia soil.
It seems to me her cup of vengeance must be nearly full, her hour of retribution near at hand.
How long, how long will it be till the crows pick the bones of the invaders of her soil?
I expect the next news to be that our armies have visited a terrible punishment upon the hirelings and mercenaries of Lincoln's despotism.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Affairs at camp Grice.
div3.p: This is one of the most pleasant situations on the harbor, bearing a full view of all the forts below us, and having a direct aim upon the enemy if they ever should dare to attempt an entrance to our cities.

All is quiet here, and we have only to wait, for Lincoln's horde of mercenary thieves to attack our battery before we can make ourselves useful in the present campaign.
Our boys can never be satisfied till they have a pull at them with our big guns; for I tell you when the cannon doth roar, the hot shot will bore.
Our company is increasing daily, under the popular and efficient commander, Capt Edward Kearns, a true son of Virginia, a patriot, and a "bold soger boy."

We had an election a few days ago for a 3d Lieutenant, which resulted in the promotion of acting 3d Sergeant Henry A. Allen; and as honor is due him, I must say that a more whole-souled, generous, persevering, brave and loyal son of Virginia never lived.
This is no flattery, but the out-pouring of a true friend of his and his company.
We have also stationed here the Craney Island Artillery, Capt. J. T. Kilby, of Nansemond county--men of true Southern metal.

There was a rumor afloat yesterday, that the Mediterranean fleet had anchored in the Roads; but I don't think it reliable.
Our esteemed townsman, Lieut. Wm. H. Murdangh, late of the U. S. Navy, arrived here yesterday from New York.
He had been held there as a prisoner from the store ship Supply.
He resigned his commission at sea, whilst on the frigate Sabine, at which time he was flag-lieutenant.
He has come among us to help fight our battles.
The Plymouth has been raised, and the Germantown is nearly so.

div3.head: From Manassas Junction.
div3.p: --The Lynchburg Republican, of yesterday, says:

q.p: Gentlemen who reached here yesterday from Manassas Junction, say that only three regiments are now at that place, all of the other forces under Gen. Beauregard's command having been advanced in the direction of Alexandria.
Two South Carolina companies are within four miles of Alexandria.
The reported capture of nine South Carolinians is still asserted, but there is no confirmation.
Among the troops yet at the Junction is the entire regiment of Col. Garland, made up almost entirely of companies from this city and county.

div3.head: Brush with Mexicans on the Rio Grande.
div3.p: The Galveston Civilian publishes the following extract of a letter from Laredo, Webb county, Texas, dated 2d inst.:

q.p:
Captain Donaldson's company, when out scouting between Roma and Claranio, Wednesday, 29th ult., were fired on by a party of Mexicans from the opposite side of the Rio Grande, near Guerrero.
The Rangers quickly returned the fire, killing a notorious character and leading man amongst the banditti, named Antonio Aches.

Neither party attempted to cross the river.
The Mexicans retreated beyond range of the Texas rifles, and the latter quietly proceeded on their scout.

div3.head: Mrs. Francis Ket Blunt.
div3.p:
--Mrs. Francis Key Blunt is giving dramatic readings in Willis' Rooms, St. James, London.
A writer' speaking of her first appearance, says:

q.p:
The place was literally filled with one of the finest audiences that the West End can produce.
Park Lane and Piceadilly turned out to honor the daughter of the author of the "Star Spangled Banner." Never did an artiste have a better opportunity to win complete success, and never did I see a more lamentable failure.

div3.p: So says a correspondent of the Times; but his critical judgment may be accounted for by the prejudice displayed in the following:

q.p: "And this lady, Mrs. Blunt, the daughter of one of America's noblest and most patriotic sons, is an avewed "

div3.head: The late shooting case.
div3.p:
--Henry Cooper, who shot John Lindsey in the Dime Saloon on Wednesday morning, was carried before the Mayor yesterday.
Several witnesses were examined.
One of them, Mr. Harrison, of Arkansas, testified that Mr. L. was choking Cooper when he fired; another, Mr. Hayward, testified that he did not see Mr. L. have his hand on prisoner, but that he was advancing on him, telling him to shoot, when the pistol was presented and discharged; another witness testified that Cooper said he would have shot C. G. Thompson, who arrested him, if he had not thought he was an officer.
Capt. A. G. Dickinson, of the Palmer Guards, Texas Battalion, to which accused is attached, said that he had been informed by Dr. Peachy and another physician that there was an entire probability that Mr. Lindsey would soon recover from the effects of the wound.
It was also stated that the ball, which had passed entirely through the stomach and lodged in the thigh, had been extracted.
From the favorable representations made of the condition of Mr. Lindsey, the Mayor was induced to think it possible he might be able to attend the examination if postponed till to-morrow.
It was accordingly laid over till that time.

div3.head: Beat his wife.
div3.p:
--The name of Francis Haley was called in Court yesterday before the Mayor for beating his wife.
On Mr. Chalkley, police officer, enunciating the name of "Blivolina Haley," in stentorian tones, a little woman came forward who testified that she was the wife of the prisoner and lived on Canal street, the other side of the Basin; that he had given her a severe drubbing on Sunday night and renewed the attack Wednesday, finishing by turning her out of doors.
The last fuss was occasioned by Haley ordering his little daughter, 6 years old, to go after a bucket of water.
His wife said she did not think the child strong enough to be sent on such an errand, and got thumped for making the suggestion.
Defendant was committed for one year in default of surety in the sum of $150, and ordered to work in the chain-gang for 60 days. The man proved to have the delirium tremens on him, as after taking his seat in the prisoner's dock he was attacked with a fit, accompanied by the most horrid grimaces, contortions, &c., we ever saw. He was taken out and sprinkled with water and a glass of brandy given him, after which he revived and was sent to jail.

In justice to Haley, it ought to be added that he was in no condition yesterday to explain the reason for his conduct.
